drawing_instructions.thinking: Looking at the blank canvas, I want to express sadness through drooping, downward-flowing lines that suggest tears or rain. I'll start with gentle, downward-curved lines in a soft blue color to create a melancholic atmosphere. These will be placed in the upper portion of the canvas, like tears falling from unseen eyes.

I see light blue wiggly lines suggesting falling tears. To deepen the feeling of sadness, I want to add some darker, heavier teardrops at the bottom of these streams, like tears collecting and pooling. I'll use the marker brush with a darker shade of blue to create small teardrop shapes beneath each wiggle line, symbolizing the weight of accumulated sorrow.

Looking at the falling tears on the canvas, I want to add a subtle, misty effect around them to enhance the melancholic atmosphere. I'll use the spray brush to create soft, scattered dots around each teardrop, suggesting a foggy, lonely environment. This will add depth to the sadness and create a sense of isolation. I'll focus on the areas around the tear pools, as if they're dissolving into the emptiness.

The canvas now shows a pattern of falling tears with misty effects. To amplify the feeling of sadness, I want to add another gentle, wiggly line that seems to be falling more slowly, as if hesitant and weighed down by sorrow. I'll place it at the far left of the existing pattern, maintaining the visual rhythm while adding to the melancholic atmosphere. This will complete the sequence of falling tears and create a balanced composition that expresses deep sadness.

Looking at the sad scene of falling tears and misty spots, I want to add one final wiggly line to complete the composition. I'll place it on the right side to balance the leftmost tear, creating a sense of symmetry in the sorrow. The gentle, wavy line will mirror the existing pattern of falling tears, emphasizing the continuous flow of sadness.

Looking at the canvas filled with falling tears and misty effects, I want to emphasize the weight of sadness by adding a gentle ripple effect beneath one of the teardrops. The spray pattern and blue teardrops create a melancholic atmosphere, and I'll use a wiggle brush with a very light blue to suggest the gentle rippling of a tear as it hits an unseen surface. This will be placed under one of the central teardrops, enhancing the feeling of quiet, rippling sorrow.

The canvas shows a melancholic scene of falling tears with misty effects and gentle ripples. To enhance the feeling of overwhelming sadness, I want to add a new sequence of small wiggling lines in a lighter blue shade above one of the tear clusters. These lines will appear like small, trembling waves of emotion, suggesting the moment just before tears form. I'll place them in the upper right area where there's still some space, making them shorter and more hesitant than the main tear streams, expressing vulnerability and fragility.

Looking at the canvas with its falling tears, misty spots, and gentle ripples, I want to add a heavier element that represents the weight of deep sorrow. I'll use the marker brush with a darker blue shade to create a large, heavy teardrop pooling at the bottom center of the composition. This will serve as a focal point that grounds all the falling tears above it, symbolizing how all our sadness eventually collects into a deep pool of emotion.

Looking at the canvas with its delicate tears, mist, and the heavy pool below, I want to add another layer of melancholy by creating a gentle, downward-curved line with the wiggle brush that suggests a drooping, weeping form. I'll place it near the bottom left of the composition, curving down towards the large teardrop pool, like a wilting flower stem bending under the weight of sadness. This will enhance the overall feeling of heaviness and descent that pervades the piece.

Looking at the poignant scene of falling tears and misty sorrow, I want to add another gentle ripple in the large pool at the bottom. This ripple will symbolize how sadness continues to resonate even when tears settle. I'll use the wiggle brush with a light sky blue color to create a soft, concentric wave pattern within the larger teardrop pool, suggesting quiet, contained grief.

Looking at the emotional scene of falling tears and ripples, I want to add one more element that captures deep melancholy - a series of increasingly faint wiggly lines on the left side, like tears that are fading away into nothingness. I'll use the wiggle brush with the lightest shade of Sky Blue to create these diminishing lines, suggesting how even our tears eventually fade, though the sadness remains. I'll place them in a gentle diagonal pattern, each line slightly shorter than the last, creating a sense of dissipating sorrow.

Looking at this deeply emotional scene of falling tears, I want to add more weight to the feeling of sadness by creating a large, heavy teardrop shape in the bottom right corner. This will use the marker brush with the darkest shade of Sky Blue (#0D2E39), representing the heaviest, most concentrated form of sorrow. The teardrop will be larger than the others, suggesting how sadness can grow and become overwhelming. I'll add slight transparency to create depth and let it interact with the existing elements, showing how our deepest sorrows can blend with and amplify each other.

Looking at the canvas filled with tears and mist, I want to add another cluster of rain-like teardrops in the upper left area where there's still some space. I'll use the spray brush to create a diffused, misty effect that suggests tears forming in the air before they fall. This will add to the overwhelming feeling of sadness and create balance with the existing elements. The spray pattern will be slightly dispersed, like tears blurred through watery eyes.

Looking at the melancholic scene with its falling tears and misty effects, I want to add another set of delicate, wavy lines that suggest quiet sobbing. I'll use the wiggle brush with the lightest Sky Blue shade (#E5F4F9) to create gentle, trembling lines in the upper portion of the canvas. These lines will be shorter and more hesitant than the existing ones, expressing that moment when emotions are so overwhelming that even tears struggle to form. I'll place them near the top right where there's still space, creating a sense of vulnerability and emotional fragility.

Looking at the somber composition of falling tears and cloudy sorrow, I want to add one final element that represents the deepest feeling of melancholy. I'll create a large, diffused cloud of despair using the spray brush in the upper right area. This misty cluster will appear to be the source of several tears, represented by gentle wiggle lines falling from it. The spray pattern will be dense in the center and fade out at the edges, like a heavy heart full of unshed tears.
